title: 104_hr925
content:
The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" ensures that no law or agency action should diminish the value of privately owned property. Federal agencies must exercise authority to prevent such limitations and property owners have the right to compensation. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action diminishes the property's value by 20% or more. If the value decreases by over 50%, the owner can choose to sell that portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used against the agency's limitation, even if the action is later revoked. If an agency action diminishes property value by 20% or more, the Federal Government must compensate the owner. If the value decreases by over 50%, the owner can sell that portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used against the agency's limitation, even if the action is later rescinded. If the owner refunds the compensation amount to the Treasury of the United States, adjusted for inflation, the property may be used. SEC. 4. EFFECT OF STATE LAW.

No compensation under this Act if use is a nuisance or already prohibited by State law or local zoning ordinance.

SEC. 5. EXCEPTIONS.

No compensation for agency actions to prevent hazard to health, safety, or damage to specific property. No compensation for agency actions under Federal navigation servitude, except for wetlands.

SEC. 6. PROCEDURE. An owner must request compensation from the agency within 180 days of receiving notice of the agency action. The agency can negotiate the compensation amount with the owner, and if an agreement is not reached within 180 days, the owner can choose arbitration or civil action for compensation. Arbitration procedures will be similar to those under title 9, United States Code. An owner can choose arbitration or civil action for compensation if an agreement is not reached with the agency within 180 days. Arbitration procedures will be similar to those under title 9, United States Code. In a civil action, the owner may obtain relief and be entitled to attorney's fees and other litigation costs if they prevail. The agency is liable for prompt payment of any award made to the owner. The court awards interest on compensation from the limitation time. Payments to owners and judgments are made from the agency's annual appropriation. If funds are insufficient, the agency head must seek appropriation for the next fiscal year. SEC. 7. LIMITATION. Any payment under this Act by the United States is subject to the availability of appropriations. SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by limitations on property use about their rights and compensation procedures under this Act. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit any constitutional right to compensation. Payment under this Act does not grant the Federal Government any additional rights except for use limitations resulting from agency action. The term "property" in this Act refers to land and the right to use or receive water. A use of property is considered limited by an agency action if a legal right to use the property no longer exists due to the action. The term "agency action" includes the making of a grant to a public authority conditioned upon an action by the recipient that would constitute a limitation if done directly by the agency. The term "specified regulatory law" includes section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The term "specified regulatory law" includes various laws such as the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act, the Food Security Act, the Reclamation Acts, the Federal Land Policy Management Act, and the Forest and Rangeland Act. The term "fair market value" is defined as the most probable price at which property would change hands between a willing buyer and seller in a competitive market. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories. The term "law of the State" encompasses the laws of a state. The term "law of the State" includes laws of political subdivisions within a State, as well as territories and possessions of the United States. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 3, 1995. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
